She says at the beginning that the genome of the virus matches sequences on record for a coronavirus that was studied at the Wuhan lab. The most important details are a segment that 100% matches an envelope protein of a coronavirus discovered by the Wuhan lab -- this lab was acquisitioned by the Chinese military in 2015, before the discovery of that particular strain. There is also a 100% match to a segment of an HIV virus - the s2 receptor. This is true, has been widely talked about, and there are plenty of mainstream sources saying that much, and you can check the sequencing for yourself on the BLAST database search tool. The debate is whether these things could have happened naturally. "Studies" that have mainly come from Chinese scientists claim that these are coincidences, with the reasoning that there are easier ways to weaponize a coronavirus than merge it with HIV -- that is a ridiculous reasoning and does not rule out the possibility they were experimenting with viruses. They basically say it's not man-made because people can create much more deadly viruses. It is possible that they experimented with HIV and other viruses; we don't know, and there's no way to know 100%.  But these studies fail to mention how matches like these are very rare in cross-species infections - an opinion given by other reputable scientists. Plus, Nobel prize winner for discovering HIV Luc Montagnier agrees with her and says that evolution of the virus shows deterioration of the HIV segment and that this deterioration shows that piece was artificially added and the virus is essentially rejecting it. It's also not an uncommon practice to tamper with viruses; look up modified virus on nature magazine and you'll get results. Later in September, Yan co-authored a pre-print research paper named "Unusual Features of the SARS-CoV-2 Genome Suggesting Sophisticated Laboratory Modification Rather Than Natural Evolution and Delineation of Its Probable Synthetic Route."[28] Three other researchers were listed as co-authors, but the SCMP was unable to find any prior work from them.[29] The paper was uploaded to the Zenodo website, an open-access repository where anyone can post their research.[30] The paper is affiliated with the Rule of Law Society, founded by Steve Bannon and Guo Wengui.[28][30] The Rule of Law Society had not previously published scientific or medical research.[30] Yan had previously appeared on Bannon's "War Room" podcast.[29][30]

According to the paper's abstract, "SARS-CoV-2 shows biological characteristics that are inconsistent with a naturally occurring, zoonotic virus" and that it could have been created in a lab in approximately six months.[31][32] According to Newsweek, several experts in evolutionary biology and infectious disease, including Jonathan Eisen and Carl Bergstrom, said the paper did not include new information, contained multiple unsubstantiated claims and had a weak scientific case.[28] According to Angela Rasmussen, a virologist at Columbia University, the paper was "basically all circumstantial and some of it is entirely fictional".[30]

Dr. Li-Meng Yan's claims ought to be treated with a healthy degree of scepticism and more than a pinch of salt.
In September 2020, Yan co-authored a pre-print research paper named "Unusual Features of the SARS-CoV-2 Genome Suggesting Sophisticated Laboratory Modification Rather Than Natural Evolution and Delineation of Its Probable Synthetic Route." Three other researchers were listed as co-authors, but the South China Morning Post (SCMP) was unable to find any prior work from them. The paper was uploaded to the Zenodo website, an open-access repository where anyone can post their research. The paper is affiliated with the Rule of Law Society, founded by far right anti-communists Steve Bannon and Guo Wengui. The Rule of Law Society had not previously published scientific or medical research. Yan had previously appeared on Bannon's anti- China "War Room" podcast.
According to the paper's abstract, "SARS-CoV-2 shows biological characteristics that are inconsistent with a naturally occurring, zoonotic virus" and that it could have been created in a lab in approximately six months. According to Newsweek, several experts in evolutionary biology and infectious disease, including Jonathan Eisen and Carl Bergstrom, said the paper did not include new information, contained multiple unsubstantiated claims and had a weak scientific case. According to Angela Rasmussen, a virologist at Columbia University, the paper was "basically all circumstantial and some of it is entirely fictional".

Any such deliberate manipulation of the naturally occurring SARS-CoV-2 (the virus underlying COVID-19) would be exquisitely traceable via subsequent in-depth analyses. Specifically, if artificial genetic manipulation had been performed, one of the several reverse-genetic systems available for betacoronaviruses would likely have been leveraged. It's certainly possible for the Chinese government to do such a thing, but it's certainly not likely. More evidence would be needed that it was a deliberate release. Why?

-- It would be considered an act of war. Why would the government take that chance? The possible ramifications for China would be horrendous, and very little to gain.
-- Sure, it may have been intended to crash the world's economy, but how could the Chinese government have been confident it could be stopped in Wuhan and then spread to the rest of the planet? As it turns out, the Chinese economy will grow by 2% this year, and the US economy will contract... but they could not possibly have been confident it would play out like that.
-- Releasing the virus in the city of Wuhan makes no sense. It could have gotten out of control and killed half the city and spread to other cities quickly. If China had such a plan, they certainly would have released the virus out of the country. But even that makes no sense because they would have so little to gain and the chances of causing a war would be considerable.
-- China is ALREADY winning economically. Depending on how the numbers are counted, they are the largest economy in the world and getting further ahead daily. They don't NEED to pull a stunt like this.

CBC News Oct 3rd 2019 Xiangguo Qiu, her husband Keding Cheng and an unknown number of her students from China were RCMP Escorted from Canada's only level-4 lab on July 5, 2019.
Security access for the couple and the Chinese students was revoked.
Sources say this comes several months after IT specialists for the NML entered Qiu's office after-hours and replaced her computer. Her regular trips to China also started being denied.
People working inside the lab told¬†CBC¬†News this week¬†they have heard the couple¬†may return to work soon.¬†
Several of them, who asked not to be¬†identified for fears of¬†retribution, say¬†there have always been questions about Qiu's trips to China¬†‚Äî and what information and technology she was sharing with researchers there.
Xiangguo Qiu ‚Äî who was escorted out of the Winnipeg lab in July amid¬†an RCMP investigation into what's being described by Public Health Agency of Canada as a possible "policy breach" ‚Äî was invited to go to the Wuhan National Biosafety Laboratory of the Chinese Academy of Sciences twice a year for two years, for up to two weeks each time.
"This will be third-party funded, and therefore no cost to [the Public Health Agency of Canada]," say the documents, obtained through access to information requests. The identity of the third-party was redacted.
During a Sept. 19-30, 2017, trip, she also met with collaborators in Beijing, the documents say, but their names have also been blacked out.
Qiu is a medical doctor from Tianjin, China.
head of the Vaccine Development and Antiviral Therapies section in the Special Pathogens Program at the lab, Qiu's primary field is immunology. Her research focuses on vaccine development, post-exposure therapeutics and rapid diagnostics of viruses.
Cheng also works at the lab as a biologist. He has published research papers on HIV infections, Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), E. coli infections and Creutzfeldt-Jakob Syndrome.¬†
While there are few details available, experts say this could be a case of intellectual property theft or¬†technology leakage to China.
"The National Microbiology Laboratory would have some pretty sensitive biological research material that ... could be shared either with or without authorization with foreign countries," said¬†Gordon Houlden, director of the University of Alberta's China Institute."
Source : CBC News Oct 3rd 2019
